titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.31 Richmond, Va. February 5, 1863. price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Conscript shot.
div3.p:
--Dibrell Talley, who, for eight months, had been eluding the conscript officers, was overhauled at his residence, in Dinwiddle county, Va., on Monday: but, going into the upper story of an out house with a gun, defied the enrolling officers to take him. Persuasion being found useless.
Talley was shot, and it is believed, mortally wounded.

div3.head: Seizure of blockade goods.
div3.p: --The New York Mounted Cavalry (Dodge's, from Suffolk,) seized $30,000 worth of goods at Sandy Cross, Gates county, N. C., last week, owned by Winslow & Russell, and intended for the Confederate lines — The Yankee papers say the goods came from Norfolk.

div4.p: --The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M, by Mr. Hunter of Va.
Mr. Simms, of Ky., introduced a bill "to take private property for public use, by paying to the owner or owners a just compensation," which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Wigfall, of Texas, introduced a bill to regulate impressments, which was referred to the same committee.

Mr. Sparrow, of La., from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back resolutions of the Georgia Legislature relative to Quartermasters, &c., and asked that the committee be discharged from the further consideration thereof.
Agreed to

The Senate resumed the consideration of the bill to organize the Supreme Court, with the amendment thereto.
The debate was continued by Mr. Hill, of Ga., in opposition to Mr. Clay's motion to strike out the 45th and 46th sections of the Judicial Act of the Provisional Congress.
On the conclusion of Mr. Hill's speech, the floor was obtained by Mr. Phelan, of Miss., when the bill was informally passed over.
A message on the subject of Indian Affairs was received from the President, and referred to the appropriate committee.
At 20 minutes to 3 o'clock the Senate went into secret session, and adjourned on the opening of the doors.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock.

Resolutions.--Mr Read, of Kentucky, offered a resolution, which was agreed to, directing the name of Col. R. P. Trabue, commanding the Kentucky brigade, mentioned for gallant conduct in the battle of Shiloh, to be property printed — the name having been printed "Fabric" in one report, and "Wobnies" in another.

By Mr. Collier, of Va: "Joint resolutions of thanks to Gen. Roger A. Pryor, and the officers and men under his command, for gallant conduct and signal success over the enemy at Kelley's, near the Blackwater, Va." The following are the resolutions:

Resolved by the Congress of the Confederate States, That the thanks of Congress are eminently due, and are hereby tendered, to Brigadier General Roger A. Pryor, and the officers and men under his command, for the signal gallantry, cool courage, and patriotic prowess evinced in the recent engagement with the enemy under Gen. Corcoran, at Kelley's, near the line of the Blackwater, Va., on the " day of January, 1863, inflicting a heavy loss and discouraging defeat upon the Federal army, and shedding a new lustre on Confederate arms.
Resolved, That the President be requested to communicate, in appropriate orders the foregoing resolution to General Pryor, his officers and men.

Bills Reported and Referred.--By Mr. Hodge, of Ky.: An act for the establishment and equalization of the grade of officers of the navy of the Confederate States, and for other purposes — placed on the calendar and ordered to be printed.
By Mr. Helt, of Ga: An act to provide for the payment of slaves, horses, and other properly lost, captured, or destroyed in the military service of the Confederate States,--referred to Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Department.

Appropriation Bill--The House then, in Committee of the Whole, (Mr. Russell, of Va., in the chair,) commenced the consideration of the appropriation bill, which had been made the special order.
The bill was read through by clauses, and reported back to the House without amendment.
Mr. Jones called for the main question, which was sustained, and the bill placed upon its passage, and adopted.

The bill, as passed, appropriates among sums, the following, for the purposes specified: Compensation and mileage of members and delegates of the House of Representatives, $174,200; compensation and mileage of the members of the Senate, 29,900; for Treasury Department, compensation of Secretary of Treasury, Assistant Secretary, Comptroller, clerks, &c., 257,897; for transfer of funds to foreign parts, 5,000,000; for engraving and printing Treasury notes, &c., 350,000 for transmission of Confederate States funds, 200,000; for War Department, compensation of Secretary of War, Assistant Secretary, Chief of Bureau clerks, &c., 96,750; for incidental and contingent expenses of War Department 50,000; for pay of horses killed in battle, 125,000, for pay of property pressed into service, under appraisement, 187,500; for pay of nurses and cooks, not enlisted or volunteers, 10,000; for pay of matrons, assistant matrons, and ward matrons, 240,000, for pay of ward masters, 150,000; for pay of hospital laundresses, 50,000; for establishment and support of military hospitals, 150,000, for Post-Office Department, compensation of Postmaster-General, Chiefs of Bureau, clerks &c., 47,408, for salaries of Judges, Attorneys and Marshals, &c., 25,000; for printing and binding of both Houses of Congress, 25,000; for purchase of paper for the Executive Department and Congress, 25,000.

Mr. Gartrell, of Ga., from the Judiciary Committee, reported back a bill to "aid committees of Congress in the investigation of matters referred to them, and to punish false swearing before said committees." The rules were suspended and the bill taken up, and, after considerable discussion, was made the special order for Monday next, and ordered to be printed.
On motion, the House then adjourned.
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M., and was called to order by the Lieut. Governor, Prayer by Rev. Dr. J. C. McCabe.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--By Mr. Whittle: On making certain classes of persons therein named liable to taxation, in addition to the taxes which they now pay. By Mr. Christion, of Augusta: On reporting House bill authorizing the appointment of county agents and storekeepers to supply families of soldiers and indigent citizens with the necessaries of life at prime cost.
A bill to amend the act authorizing persons who have furnished substitutes to be relieved from service, was passed.
On motion of Mr. Newlon, at 3 o'clock, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock M. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Reid.

Mr. Ambers submitted a preamble and resolutions reciting that the high prices now demanded for all the necessaries of life was a just cause of complaint by the people, and that the subject having been recommended to the attention of the Legislature by both the State and Confederate Executives, the Legislature was of the opinion that the prices were not altogether attributable to the scarcity of the articles, but to the lack of facilities for transportation whereby they fall into the hands of speculators, who horde them up and prey upon the wants of the people, that it is the duty of Government to allow transportation for all necessaries of life, the property of private citizens, over all railroads and other modes of transportation over which they have control.
The third resolution calls upon the Governor to lay the subject before the Confederate authorities.
On the further motion of Mr. Ambers, the resolutions were referred to the Committee on Confederate Relations.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--The following resolutions of inquiry were introduced: By Mr. Toml'n: Into the expediency of requiring by law all internal improvement companies to receive and deliver by weight all grain for transportation.
By Mr. Read: To amend the 12th section of an act passed March 9th, 1861, incorporating the Rockbridge Insurance Company.
Agreed to.

Mr. Worsham presented a petition from Mr. Read, Superintendent of the Model Farm belonging to the North Carolina and Virginia Union Agricultural Society, representing that the injury sustained by this property during the present war — the buildings, &c., having been used by the Government for hospital purposes — it was now a burtten to the Society rather than otherwise; and asking that the same be exempt from taxation during the war. --Referred to Committee on Finance.

On motion of Mr. Grattan, the rules were suspended, in order to take up the bill refunding money received from certain persons for exemption from military service.
The bill was explained by Mr. G., and passed — ayes 37 noes none.

The hour having arrived for the consideration of the order of the day — the bill for the suppression of extortion — that bill was taken up. Numerous amendments were proposed to the various sections of the bill, and a promiscuous debate was indulged in in relation to them, during which Mr. Rarbour reminded the House that the session would end in twenty two days--or at least the pay of members would cease at the expiration of that time.

The consideration of the bill was extended so far as the ninth section, which M. Hunter moved to strike out, and upon which he addressed the House, declaring this conviction that the whole matter was illegal and against the organic laws of the land, and calculated if adopted to involve the people of the State in interminable litigation.
At 3 o'clock, on motion of Mr. Grattan, the subject was postponed until 12½ o'clock to- morrow.

Mr. Grattan moved that the House adjourn.
Agreed to.

div3.p: Col. J. D. Imboden has been commissioned a Brigadier General. From Vicksburg — The Canal — Transports to go Through — Grant's Army There — The Force of the Enemy.

The first skirmish of the second siege of Vicksburg occurred on the 25th ult., between Colonel Harrison's Texas cavalry and the Federal cavalry, under Colonel Stewart, on Walnut Bayou.
The Vicksburg Whig says:

q.p:
On Friday morning they attacked our cavalry, whom they found in camp.
Our men immediately got behind a levee and formed into line of battle, on foot, not having time to saddle their horses.
At the first fire the Yankee chief of cavalry, Colonel Stewart, formerly of McClernand's staff, fell mortally wounded, having been pierced by four halls.
A lively fire was kept up for some time, when L. McCall attempted to flank the enemy with twenty men. Perceiving this, the Yankees put spurs to their horses and fled precipitately, hotly pursued by our men, who by this time had succeeded in getting their horses.
Some fifteen of the enemy were wounded.
Singular as it may seem, not one of our men received a scratch.
Colonel Stewart was taken by our men, but lingered only a short time.
Said he, before he expired, "If you can send a message to Gen. McClernand, tell him I died fighting for my country" Papers found on his person gave a history of the late trip to Vicksburg, and a subsequent one up to the Post of Arkansas, and memorandums of the capture of that place.

div3.p: Speaking of the work done in opening the new canal, which is expected to change the channel of the Mississippi and prevent its running by Vicksburg, the Whig says:

q.p:
The enemy appear to be doing nothing except work on the famous canal.
A gentleman from Arkansas, who left their lines Saturday evening, say they had thousands of troops at work widening and deepening it. Saturday evening they turned the water in, but the body passing through was small.
The enemy, however, express their determination to make a cut-off and thus isolate Vicksburg; and as they have every facility for successfully performing such a work we shall not be surprised if in four weeks there is a sufficient body of water passing through the canal to admit of the largest steamer.
It, therefore, behooves to prepare defences at some point or points farther down.
The fortifying of Ellis's Cliffs, below Mutcher, might be a good move, as it is evident the enemy intend making a desperate effort to get their whole force by here to assist Banks in reducing Port Hudson, when they will return to this place.
Grand Gulf and Rodney are eligible positions, but a cut-off can be as easily made at either of those places as here.

div3.p: A gentleman, who came from the enemy's lines over the river, on Saturday, says that, on Friday evening, four 32-pounders and a battery of light artillery were hauled across and placed in position below Burney's. It was these guns, we suppose, that fired on the steamer Vicksburg as she was coming up on Saturday evening. Three shots struck her, but did no serious injury.
A letter from Vicksburg, dated the 27th ultimo, to the Mobile Advertiser, says:

q.p:
Gen. Smith, the Yankee officer who was wounded in the battle on the 29th ult., at Chickasaw Ba you, is at present superintending the movements of the enemy and the opening of the canal.
They say that they do not expect the canal to be of sufficient dimensions to let the gunboats through, and that it is the calculation for the latter to come by the river and attack our batteries, or to pass by them and get below the city.
But they think that in a few days there will be water enough in the canal to float their transports through and then they can land their troops below the city, and act in conjunction with an attacking force from ashore.

div3.p:
So far as the taking of Vicksburg is concerned, the canal will do them no good whatever.
Our defences below the city are as strong as these above, which fact was proved last summer by the attempt of Com. Farraput's fleet against the city.
If the Yankees land a force and give us a land fight in that quarter, they will learn that we are as well prepared for them there as anywhere else.
We feel no hesitation in expressing a wish they should land a force either above or below.
The result of such a move could not be doubtful.

The force being brought down to reinforce Gen. Sherman, it is now reliably ascertained, is no other than Gen. Grant's army.
When the two armies are united the estimated strength is supposed to be eighty thousand though many place the figures at one hundred thousand.

For the last two days there has been no movement among the enemy, further than the arrival of reinforcements.
Transports with fresh troops are constantly seen arriving and landing troops, after which they again immediately return up the river.
Ninety-two boats have been seen to disembark soldiers, but how many they carried is not known.--The force now on shore is supposed to be near seventy thousand.
Yesterday was not marked with much activity amongst them, except the increasing area of their camps, which are growing in extent every day.

For the last three days the elements have been unpropitious for military operations, particularly in the swamp occupied by the Yankees.
The heavy rains have put a quietus upon their plans for the present.
It is reported that Gen. Sherman threatens to starve out the garrison at Vicksburg by destroying the Southern Railroad, which will compel the surrender of the city without a fight.

div3.head: A history of the Gorilla — a Glance at his Early life and Associations.
div3.p:
A correspondent of the Jackson Mississippian gives that paper a biography of the present ruler of the United States.
He was born about 30 miles from Bowling Green, Kentucky, in a locality that at that period was considered socially as the "veriest low grounds" of the state.
The writer proceeds:

The Lincoln family of Kentucky is one of the lowest and most disrespectable in that State.
Abraham is one of four brothers who lived with their father and a "woman claiming to be the wife of old man Lincoln and the mother of the boys"--They had no farm, no stock, nor property of any kind save the house in which they lived and supported themselves by levying black mail on the property of their neighbors.
So disreputable had they become, and so annoying were their "raids" upon their neighbors' stock yards, cribs, gardens, &c., that they were notified to quit the country, agreeably to which the family moved to the more congenial soil of Indians.
A short time prior to the removal, Abe (then but a little lad) shipped as a "hand" on one of the flat boats navigating Green river and the Ohio, into which it falls, and the Mississippi, and trading chiefly in hay and hoop poles.
When the craft arrived at Vicksburg the owner sold out his stock of hay and hoop poles, dismissing his "hands," who, taking passage in an up-river boat, were in due time landed the detectable town of Cairo.
Here "Abe" left the river, and sought the interior of the State of Illinois.
He had never been to school a day in his life, his conversation was not only rude, but partaking strongly of the parental and fraternal bias of profanity and vulgarity, his person was uncouth and forbidding, and his morals. (God save the mark!) were "deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked." But he was from Kentucky, and to be from Kentucky then was a distinguished honor, for Kentucky's name was a synonym for chivalry and high-toned honor and patriotism.--Alas!
"How are the mighty fallen!"

and although he could not claim any interest in that (once) gallant State's reputation, yet a portion of the prestige of his native State went with him, and the "suckers" who had commenced to how themselves out a living from the forests of Illinois, gave "Abe" employment at the only honest business he was fit for namely, "mauling rails," for which he was to receive fifteen dollars per month.
He spent the winter in the woods on the edge of a prairie, not a thousand miles from Springfield, saving his wages, and in the following spring went up to Indiana to see his father and brothers.
Returning to Illinois, he found one of the "boxes" of an election precinct had been established near the "clearing" where he had been at work during the winter, and with a con amore penchant established a "grocery" or "doggery" at the point where the ballots of the suckers were to be deposited.
Here was the corner-stone of his popularity and future success.
Here he learned, while dealing out the vile drug, most happily yclept "bust head," to the sturdy suckers, that inexhaustible store of anecdotes which, "with his elbows on his knees, and his head in his hands, and his feet upon the topmost round of his chair," he still deals out to the bored visitants of the White House.
A grocery keeper on a remote clearing in the back woods of Illinois!
How the disgusting realities of such a life rise up before the mind's eye!
With what ease could Lincoln, cradled in infamy and vice, glide into the impure, the loathsome, and devilish association of such a life!
Here was the school-house of the future President of the United States, this the vestibule of that Temple whose god is the Devil, whose doctrine was hypocrisy and lust a doctrine that has culminated in the proclamation of the 1st January, 1863, inviting servile insurrection with its train of unmentionable calamities and dark and damnable deeds and which will at last lead its votary to the face of a Robespierre, a Marat, or John Brown.

Young Abraham's grocery became the favorite resort of the dissipated and rowdyish suckers, and many a fisticuffs and set to was had before and behind Abe's bar. The Justice of the Peace for the beat of the county of " had reason to thank Abe's "villainous compound" for sundry fees, the product of petty assault and battery cases, etc., etc., brought before his honor, and an enterprising young lawyer from the wooden nutmeg State down with his books and parchment to practice his profession (I) in one of the corners of Abe's caravansary.
Abe took him in with an eye to business; while the lawyer was away attending to court, Abe, who had learned to read, over the Yankee's limited and being gifted with the all back wood believe that he knew as much law as any member of the bar of Illinois, certainly as much as Tom Corwin or Stove Douglas, both of whom had just been admitted to the bar, and both of whom had sprung from obscurity and poverty, So Abe was admitted to the bar. He next offered himself as a candidate for the Legislature.
The patrons of his bar, his old friends, who had so often with him.
"Tippled o'er the barley bras,"

elected him to the House of Representatives, and here his effrontery and boldness, but particularly his ardent abolitionism, which had grown with his growth, and strengthened with his strength, gave him force and character with the leading Abolitionists in Illinois.
After the adjournment of the Legislature Abe went in search of a wife.
At the agricultural fair at Paris, Ky., he saw Miss Lizzle Todd Miss Lizzle Todd, now Mrs. Lincoln, was not of the Todd family proper of Kentucky.
Here, however, it a collateral branch of that family, but neither in material nor intellectual wealth a fair representative of that highly respectable family.
The Todds were plain people, else Abe Lincoln would not have dared address Miss Lizzle.
But plain as was Mr. Todd's family, he had pride enough to feel its superiority to that of Lincoln.
He knew the Lincoln family, knew its origin, its antecedents, its penchant for scurrilous and low missions, knew, like Ballot's.
"Its thoughts were low, to vice industrious," and therefore he no sooner learned that a scion of that family sought an alliance with his own than he forbid Abe his house and his daughter's society.

"Lizzle," said old man Todd, with mournful determination and pathos, "Lizzle, I would rather see you in your grave than the wife of a Lincoln!" Abe returned to Illinois and surreptitiously corresponded with Miss Todd.
Time glided on; so did the Abolition element in the West, strengthened, as it was, by daily importations from fanatical New England.
A vacancy occurred in the Congressional delegation from Illinois.
Abe offered himself as a candidate on the Abolition basis and was elected.
As a member of Congress he again sought the hand of Miss Todd, and this time was successful.
But the old man gave his consent regretting the union of his daughter with a Lincolnite, and feeling that even a membership in the Northern Congress would not atone for the disgrace.

div3.head: European News.
div3.p: --The following paragraphs are from the Nassau correspondent of the Charleston Courier, who writes under date of Jan. 14th:

Large public meetings are being held all over England for the purpose of raising funds to support the sufferers.
The colonies are also responding to the cry of distress.
Means are about to be taken here, in Nassau, to commence a subscription.
At a public meeting held in London, Lord Stanley has made a speech in which the following sentence appears:

"He expressed a hope that we should soon have seen the worst.
That depends on when the American war shall terminate.
If it last another year we have not by any means seen the worst; should it last five years, the ruin of Lancashire will be irretrievable."

The Dublin University Magazine, for December, has an article on the Lancashire troubles, entitled "Men, Masters and Cotton." After portraying the sufferings of the operatives, and paying a tribute to their patient and orderly conduct, the writer makes these significant remarks:

"It now appears that the cotton crops have been but partially destroyed.
An immense quantity awaits the breaking of the blockade for shipment.
Her Majesty's Consul at Charleston sets down the total stock of cotton in the South at 3,250,000 bales. Is it not worth running a risk to obtain this supply and light up all the factory fires again?

"The aid offered by public contributions will soon cease.
What, then, is to be done?
Is has now been shown that the most India can do for us is very little.
All our substitutes have failed.
We are thrown back on the Southern American produce.
The eyes of tens of thousands are strained Westward to discern the first streak of an approaching peace which will restore happiness to the desolated homes of Lancashire.
We have no other hope --no other reliance."
The Italics are my own. Another influential periodical, the United Service Magazine, in the December number, says.

q.p: "We shall never be free from embarrassment until we make us our minds to recognize the Confederacy, and thus do more to put an end to the miseries of the war in America and enforced idleness in Lancashire, than if we join in the half measure of mediation proposed by France, which, if not backed by force, would only irritate and give a little fresh strength to the Lincoln Government."

div3.head: Brutality in Missouri.
div3.p:
--A few weeks since Capt. Woodmail's company of Confederate cavalry were attacked by a party of Federals under Col. Rennick, whom they repulsed.
The Captain, in giving the details of the fight, says:

q.p:
The fight was near the farm of widow Ellet, who has several grandsons in the Confederate States army.
Rennick carried his dead and wounded to the front of her house called her out, and told her to look at what "her kind" had done to his men. He then took her invalid son, and her nephew Jas. Rollius, murdered them before her eyes, and applied the torch to her house and buildings destroying all her property.
He also burnt the houses of her son and son-in-law, and drove off all their negroes and horses to their camp.

div3.p:
I succeeded in getting one hundred and thirty men together and left for Dixie.
We joined the First Brigade, in Newton county, Missouri, on the 12th of September, after fighting and skirmishing with the enemy for 250 miles.

div3.head: In Bad Company.
div3.p:
--One of our editors went out to the battle-field on Wednesday in search of glory and items.
While following up the charge of McCown's division, he met a body of prisoners moving to the rear, and, intent upon an item, at once struck up a conversation with them.
Unfortunately, he was arrayed in cerulean habiliments, and upon attempting to leave was ordered by the guard to remain where he was. With a smile of ineffable contempt, he drew from his pocket a pass but what was his chagrin when he was accosted with, "I say, my boy, none of us can read: but that than trick's too old, and I'll tell yor another thing, yor damn blue bellied Yankee, if you try any more of them dodges I'll souze this thing into yor gizzard."

Think of that, oh ye tribe of brother quill drivers.
The editor of this paper the leading journal of the South, to be called a Yankee, and to be accredited with possessing an azure abdomen.--Murfreesboro' Banner.

div3.head: Affairs in Western Virginia.
div3.p: --Week before last, Capt Taylor, of Col Geo. W. Imboden's cavalry regiment, captured on the North Fork, in Pendleton county, Captain Sites and nine of his men — They are a part of a Union Home Guard who employ most of their time in stealing horses and giving information to the enemy.

Lieut. Monroe Blue, with fifteen men, made a capture, in Hampshire county, inside the enemy's lines, of sixteen horses six wagons, five prisoners and two bags of Yankee mail, on the road from Romney to Greenspring Depot. Lieut. Blue escaped with twelve horses and three prisoners, though pursued by a considerable cavalry force, and about two thousand infantry.
The mail was conveyed to a safe point, but has not yet been brought in the lines.
Lieut. Blue, during his scout, killed one Yankee captain, wounded another, and killed and wounded five privates.

div3.head: Shocking accident.
div3.p:
--Mr. George B. Jones, proprietor of the Manchester Foundry, lost his life in Petersburg on Tuesday by a most shocking accident.
He was proceeding to the depot of the Richmond train with his father-in-law, Mr. Robert Baird, and while crossing Pocahontas bridge was knocked down by a train of cars which were in the act of backing on the Government track.
One or more of the car wheels passed over Mr. Jones's left leg, striking him near the groin, and splitting the limb asunder from the groin down to and through the foot.
The leg was frightfully lacerated, and the bones of the foot crushed into many places.
The unfortunate man was immediately placed in an ambulance and taken to the Ladies' Hospital on Bollingbrock street, where, after a long delay, it was decided that in the absence of the Surgeon Dr. C. F. Couch, the patient could not be admitted.
He was then carried to a dwelling house, where several physicians were called to his assistance; but the shock to the nervous system had been so violent, that all medical aid proved unavailing.
At a quarter to seven o'clock, the unfortunate man breathed his last.
He retained his consciousness to the last, and repeatedly expressed the opinion that he could not live.
Mr. Jones was about 39 years of age, and leaves a widow and two children in Manchester.

div3.head: Prison items.
div3.p:
--The following arrivals were chronicled at Castle Thunder Tuesday; Wm. Carr, sent from C. S. Marine Hospital by Dr. Christian; J. W. Fitzpatrick, Nelson Artillery, and Samuel Huddleson, co C. 23d N. C., desertion; David Britt, arrested on the 17th September for disloyalty, and A. L. Blankinship, co D. 28th Va. late prisoner's at the Castle, died Tuesday at the Small-pox Hospital; James Garland, who was sent down by the Provost Marshal of Abingdon, Va., died at the Castle Tuesday of typhoid fever.
Twenty-six men were sent from the prison Tuesday to the Provost Marshal at Petersburg, to be forwarded to their regiments.
R. F. Thomasson and Thos. Higgins, who were arrested on the 31st of January for selling liquor, were discharged from custody Tuesday by order of Major Griswold.

The following arrivals were chronicled at Castle Thunder yesterday: W. J. Carney, Bodger's cavalry, desertion; Lewy Lynch, co A., 61st Va. and M. M. Holland, co I, 3d Va. desertion; Levy and Dempsey Purris, negroes, for piloting the Yankees in their recent fight with Gen. Pryor; C. C. Cullen and Simon Smith, sent by the Provost Marshal of Lynchburg, and ordered into confinement as substitute against; Francis Kenan, Confederate Zouaves, desertion; Thos. Martis, Letcher artilley, do; Wm. Lynchburg Beauregards do; Wm. Boydtor, do, do; J. Rose, co A, 50th Va. do; J. Edgarton on K 7th La, do; J. Dounid co. H, 4th Va. do, Jones Parker, co B, 48th Va, do; John Frant, co B, 24th Va do; Lawrence Keefe, 1st Va. Bet, do; Wm. Whatan, co D, 6th La, do. The following were discharged; Albert W. Gleclair, allas Carrington, arrested as a Yankee spy, turned over to the Mayor to be tried for horse stealing: John Edwards, allas Russell, sent to his company; James Humphries, sent to the small pox hospital; Miles Burrows, a Yankee prisoner, citizen of N. C., taken in arms against the Confederacy, died in the prison yesterday.

div3.head: Additions at the Central Depot.
div3.p:
--New Buildings.--A new our shop has just been completed by the Virginia Central Railroad Company on the lot south of the old shops, and near the terminus of 17th street. With the new smith shop built some months since, this will add very much to the facilities for repairs of the rolling stock, so much injured by the constant use to which it has been put in the transportation of troops for the Government during the last eighteen months. This building is created nearly east and west; is 154 feet long and 84 feet wide.
The covering is of state supported by an arched truce roof, and is lighted by a clear story with fifty four sky lights, and also by a sufficient number of windows — in all containing more than 1,500 panes of glass.
Attached to this edifice is a brick engine house in which is a new stationary engine, of 25 horse power, built by Messrs Ettenger & Edmond of this city, by which the machinery is to be drives.
The shop contains six tracks on which cars can be placed for repairs.
These latter are brought in by means of a side track, 710 feet long, running parallel with the smith and at right angles with the car shop, to a transfer table, on which they are moved, by means of cog wheels, to whichever track they may be needed; and after being repaired, are run out on the transfer table and placed on another side track, also connecting with the main track, running through the machine shops and yards.
In the erection of the building the plans were drown by H. D. Whitecombs; carpentering by J. R. Charles; bricklaying by. J. H. Sheppard; and stating by Rd. Kevan, or Charlottesville.

div3.head: To be Executed.
div3.p:
--At the last session of the Hustings Court, Judge Lyons presiding, Michael Buxton was arraigned, tried, and found guilty of the murder of John Delaney, and therefore sentenced to be hanged by the neck until dead on Friday, February 6th. The murder of which Buston was found guilty was perpetrated in Adams's Valley a few days before Christmas.
The Governor having positively refused to pardon him he will be hung in accordance with his sentence.
Two men are to be shot at Camp Lee on the same day.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--The alarm of fire, about 4½ o'clock yesterday morning was caused by the burning of the roof a of wooden tenement on south side of Main street, between 17th and 18th streets, which was ignited by sparks from the chimney.
The lower stories were occupied by H. A. Pearce, jeweler, and ishmael Isaacs, dry goods store; the upper part by John J. Whiteford.
The roof was almost entirely destroyed, and the premises somewhat damaged by water.
Loss $1,500, covered by insurance.
The building was the property of John W. Shields.

div3.head: A Mistake.
div3.p:
--In the case of Wm. R. Warden, before the Mayor on Tuesday on the charge of fraudulently obtaining two hhds. of sugar from Richard Cauthorn and converting the proceeds to his own use, it was stated that the defendant had been finally examined and sent before the Hustings Court.
This was an error.
Only one or two witnesses responding to their names, and the case being laid over on account of the absence of a material one, whose testimony could not be had on the occasion.

div3.head: The coldest night.
div3.p:
--Tuesday night was the coldest one since 1857.
This fact was ascertained by a comparison of the thermometer at the City Water Works, where the mercury in the tube indicated eight degrees below zero.
Should the present weather continue, our soldiers in the field must suffer considerably.
The signs of the times indicate that we shall be afforded more opportunities than we care to embrace for getting in a supply of ice sufficient to last through the summer months.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p: --Yesterday Messrs Chalkley and Baptist, of the city police, arrested a man named William Benake for feloniously stealing sugar, lard, and other articles, worth $100, the property of C. W. Spicer & Co., of the Columbian Hotel, and lodged him in the cage for examination before the Mayor.

div3.head: A ball in camp.
div3.p:
--On Tuesday night a grand ball was given at Chaffin's farm, by the officers of the Wise Legion.
There were about one hundred officers present, and a large number of ladies from Richmond and the surrounding country.
Dancing was kept up all night.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
--Benjamin W. Carter and Thomas Samani were arraigned for forging the name of Juan Pizzini to a check for $80, payable at the Exchange Bank of Virginia.
It has already been intimated that Carter was detected trying to draw the money from the bank, and that on his arrest he implicated Samani as the party who had given him the check.--No evidence was adduced to-day sufficient to warrant the Mayor in sending Samanni on for trial for felony; but he was required to give $1,000 security for his appearance as a witness and for his good behavior.
The defendant Carter was committed for final examination before the Hustings Court.

Adam Schafer, represented to be from Baltimore, charged with stealing $1,000 in Confederate States Treasury notes, the property of Thomas S. Hubbard, at the boarding house of Mrs. Graves corner of Franklin and Mayo streets on Monday night.--On the arrest of the prisoner over $350 of the stolen money were recovered from a house of doubtful repute on Locust Alley.
The testimony warranting the proceeding the prisoner was committed to jail for further examination before the Hustings Court.

Patrick Pearman, alias Botts, was charged with shooting at and severely wounding Lafayette Brooks, on 17th street, on Monday night. The case was continued, the wounds of Brooks not permitting him to attend to give his evidence against the accused.
The case of R. S. St. Clair, charged with feloniously stealing a horse, worth $250, from John S. Osborne, was continued on account of the absence of material witnesses.

Sundry members of the colored fraternity, both free and slave, having been arrested by the military police for such offences as walking with sticks and smoking in the streets, the Mayor, to encourage them in their vigilant course of conduct, ordered all the darkies to be whipped.

div3.head: Latest from Vicksburg.
div3.p:
--The Yankee ram Queen of the West, went down the river yesterday afternoon, with the supposed intention of destroying the shipping between this point and Fort Hudson.
She was fired into at Warrenton, but with no effect.

div4.head: [second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--A special dispatch to the Tribune dated Jackson, the 4th instant, says that the Federal ram Queen of the West, which passed Vicksburg on Monday morning, arrived and landed at Vidalla, opposite Natches, on the same evening.
A squad of men was sent ashore who attempted to capture Col. Zobulon York, but he escaped.
The ram then steamed down the river, doing considerable damage.

Within eight hours previous to yesterday 250 Yankee deserters arrived at Grenada.
Deserters are constantly arriving, and the country is full of them.
Not less than 500 have deserted from one division of the Yankee army.

div3.head: Fight with the enemy near Murfreesboro'.
div3.p: --The following dispatch has been received by mail from Deckam, dated Jan. 31st:

The enemy advanced 12 miles from Murfreesboro' yesterday with one brigade and six places of artillery on a foraging expedition.
They made in vigorous attack on our cavalry, shelling attack a short distance.

We concealed ourselves in the woods near Forrestville, and Anderson's brigade (which fortunately arrived) repulsed them, with a loss of 300 killed and wounded. Our loss small.
Heavy skirmishing may be looked for daily.

Gen. Johnston has issued a congratulatory order to the army of Tennessee, and will direct future movements.
He was serenaded last night at Tullahoma.

div3.head: Latest from Memphis.
div3.p: --The latest reliable information from Memphis represents that several gunboats had passed down the river, which is rising, and is now within four feet of high water mark.

There is growing dissatisfaction among the Yankees. One brigade has been placed under guard in the fortifications at Memphis.
Artillery has been placed at all the stations on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad.

div3.head: The blockade at Sabine Pass Raised.
div3.p:
--New Orleans papers received at Ponchatoula announce the raising of the blockade at Sabine Pass, and the capture of three Federal vessels by the Confederates.
No particulars received.
[Sabine Pass is the outlet of Lake-Sabine into the Gulf of Mexico, at the southwestern corner of Louisiana.]

div3.head: Another Morgan Dash.
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the Constitutionalist, dated at McMinnville, the 31 inst., says that twenty-five of Morgan's men attacked a foraging party of four hundred Yankees, with forty wagons.
Morgan succeeded in bringing off eleven wagons and thirty prisoners, and in burning a quantity of baggage.

div3.head: Large fire in Columbus.
div3.p:
--A large fire commenced here at 3 o'clock this morning.
Five or six buildings have been burned, and the fire was still raging at 4 o'clock A. M.

div3.head: The Convention of the Press.
div3.p:
--The Editorial Convention met this morning.
About twenty papers are represented.
Joseph Cilsby, of the Macon Telegraph, is President, and F. M. Elis, of the Atlanta Baptist, Secretary.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of eighty-six acres of land, in Henrico county, on the Deep-run Turnpike, at Auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Saturday, the 14th day of February, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which Lee said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A Smith, John W. Alley, and Jas. Shephard.
It contains 85 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms, Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson.
Late Sheriff of Henrico co, and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford, who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 3

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 5,000 Cords of Fine Wood, 100,000 part of Carboned Lumber, and one Steak Saw Mill.
Will be sold to the highest bidder, on Thursday, the 18th day of February, next, at the Saw Mill lately occupied by Rowland & Shriver, Sec'd, about three miles from Cabin Point, Surry co., Va. the following property to wit:

1. Horse and 8 yoke of Oxen, 1 Steam Saw Mill and Fixtures, Wagons, Carts, Carryless; also, about 100,000 feet of Lumber, principally inch boards, and from five to seven thousand cords of Fine Wood, 5 Bogie's cross out Saws, 1 pair large Patent Balances, 50 bales of Bay, and all the Fixtures, too numerous to mention, necessary to carry on a well-kept Saw Mill.
Persons wishing to purchase the wood or lumber, can have every facility for chipping to Richmond on Petersburg by the and Petersburg Railroad, which is only a short distance.
Sale to commence at 11 o'clock A. M., when terms will be made

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 31, page 2.

div3.head: The army and Navy Gazette (English) on our Generals.
div3.p:
The United Service Journal, a journal of high authority with the officers of the British army and navy, thinks that we have no Generals who know how to make use of a victory, and that all our battles, thus far, have been so many huge skirmishes, resulting in immense waste of blood, but no decisive results, and altogether unprofitable, save in so far as they have developed an immense amount of pluck on the part of our men. That our have not been pushed home to decisive results, is but too true.
Yet before we venture to condemn the Generals commanding, we should at least be placed in possession of all the circumstances of each particular case, that we may learn how far the failure was attributable to them, and whether it was possible to have secured greater advantages than they secured.
This insight into the interior of our military affairs can never be obtained until after the war shall have closed, and it shall have become no longer imprudent to make the disclosures necessary to the formation of a correct judgment.
For our own part, satisfied that our Generals, in particular instances, had cogent reasons for the line of conduct they thought fit to pursue, we shall content ourselves with observing and making it plain that their victories have been quite as decisive, and have been pushed quite as far as any ever gained by the Duke of Wellington in the three first years of his famous Peninsula campaigns.
As the Duke of Wellington is the English model of a great captain, the writer in the Journal will of course be satisfied if we can make this out.

Well, then, the Duke of Wellington landed at Lisbon to take command of the British army on the 15th day of April, 1809, bringing with him large reinforcements, especially from Ireland.
In May be advanced against Oporto, which Soult abandoned without striking a blow.
In July he advanced into the interior of Spain, and fought the bloody battle of Talavera, which was so indecisive that the French claimed the victory, and, we believe, have not relinquished the claim to this day. They had some show of right to claim it, for in a day or two after, Wellington hearing that, Soult and Nay were advancing to close upon his rear, and cut off his retreat, retired with such break-neck speed that he left behind all his sick and wounded, and never halted until he had gotten back safe to Lisbon.
He fought no other battle until the next year, (1810.) When Massena invaded Portugal he met him on the frontier at Busaco, and fought a battle in which four or five thousand men were killed and wounded on both sides.
The result was quite as undecided as that of any battle during the present war. Wellington held an impregnable position on the mountains.
Massena tried to storm it by an attack in front, failed, and drew off his men in perfectly good order, not being to the slightest degree molested by the English.
The next day he turned the position, and Wellington felt back.
The English army retired leisurely to their lines at Torres Vedras, the French pursuing them.
No other pitched battle occurred at that time, although there were frequent skirmishes.
Wellington got behind the fortifications of Torres Vedras, the most stupendous works of which history makes mention, and there, with Lisbon in his rear, and an immense English fleet of transports and ships of war riding in the Yagus and supplying him with everything he wanted direct from England, he waited until famine and disease had so reduced the forces of Massena that he was compelled to evacuate the country.
He fell back, Wellington followed, and the battle of Fuentes d' Onoro quite as indecisive as any of the rest, was fought on the 5th day of May, 1811. This last action was rather a combat than a pitched battle, and the excuse made for not rendering it decisive was that Wellington's cavalry were in an emaciated condition.
The French not only were not beaten, but they kept their ground in front of the English until want of supplies compelled them to fall back.

There was no other pitched battle in which Wellington commanded from that time to July, 1812--that is to say, for fourteen months, though in the interval he stormed the two strong fortresses of Cludad Roderigo and Badejos.
For these services he was created an Earl.
It was not until the battle of Salamanes, fought on the 22d day of July, 1812, three years and three months after he had been in the Peninsula, that he obtained overwhelming success in any pitched battle, and the battle of Vittoria, fought on the 20th day of June, 1813, was the only other occasion during the Peninsular war in which he did so. For the first of these exploits he was made a Duke, and for the second an English Field Marshal.
It seems a little hard that General Lee should be expected in six months to do what it took the greatest General England ever produced three years and two months to do, and that he should be set down as no General for not doing it. The fairer way would be to give him the same time that the Englishman enjoyed.
Who knows that his Salamanca may not come yet?
If the three first years of Wellington in Spain gave promise of a Salamanca, the six months of Lee promise greatly more.
In the number of battles fought prisoners taken, and men killed and wounded, there is no comparison what ever between the exploits of the two men. Gen. Lee has already fought more battles and taken more prisoners than the Duke of Wellington fought or took throughout his whole career from Assye to Waterloo inclusive.

We mean not to underrate the services of Wellington in the Peninsula during the three first years of his career.
He succeeded in holding Portugal and buffling the enterprises of the enemy.
Why did he not make the battle of Talavera decisive?
His apologists say because he had not men enough.
Why did he not make the battle of Busaco decisive?
The same apologists say that he was in an impregnable position, which the enemy had very foolishly assailed and did not wish to quit it, thereby exposing himself, with his inferior numbers, to the loss of all the advantages he had gained.
Why did he not make the battle of Fuentes D'Onoro decisive?
Because his cavalry was in such a condition that he could not use it with effect.
Every one of these excuses is an excellent one, and ought to be decisive of the question.
Before condemning General Lee, would it not be as well to know whether he, too, may not have had excellent reasons for not following up his advantages?
It was not until Wellington had acquired a superiority of force in the field that he was able to push his victory of Salamanca to the utmost.
Give General Lee a superiority such as Wellington had on that occasion — let Burnside cross over to attack him — and if he does not make a Waterloo business of it, then shall we acknowledge that he is no General, and does not know what to do with a victory when he has won it.

P. S.--Since the above was written, we find that the article in the United Service Journal was written by Russell, the correspondent of the London Times.
Had we known this before, we should scarcely have taken the trouble to notice it; for the man is no soldier, and has proved himself so utterly destitute of sagacity and forecast that nothing he says produces any impression.
He tells the readers of the Journal that the amount of carnage in our battle has been much below the average of European battles.
Let us try him by the Peninsula standard once more.
At the battle of Talavera the French numbered about 45,000 men. Wellington had under him 24,000 British troops, and Cuesta about 40,000 Spaniards.
After two days fighting the British General summed up his losses as follows: 800 killed, 3,900 wounded, and 650 missing--total, 5,350.
The Spaniards lost 1,250 killed and wounded. Grand total, 6,600--From the same authority we learn that the "estimates" loss of the French was 10,000.
They lost in fact about 7,000.
For this battle Sir Arthur Wellesley was created a Viscount.

Busaco is a or mountain ridge.
The road along which Massona was advancing to invade Portugal runs directly over it. It is semi circular, and the British army was posted on it, their line extending eight miles, following the circle, the two extremities being about four miles apart.
It thus formed an emphithesire, and was one of the strongest positions it was possible to conceive.
Every movement of the French army, which was in the valley below, could be seen.
This formidable post Wellington defended with 30,000 British troops and 25,000 Portuguese, who on that day fought quite as well as the British, and were, in fact, equal to any troops in Europe.
Massena had about 70,000 troops, of which 25,000 were engaged in the battle.
He lost about 4,000 men, of whom 187 were prisoners.
The English loss was about 600 killed and wounded, and that of the Portuguese about the same.

At Furnies d'onoro, the French lost 400 men killed and about 1,000 wounded. The English loss was about the same.
In none of these three battles was the success decided.
The French merely attacked impregnable positions, and fell back with loss when they could not carry them.

At Salamanca, which comes next, Wellington gained his first decided victory.
The French army was about 40,000 strong.
The English and Portuguese were 46,000, and they had a force of 15,000 Spaniards with them.
The French lost on that occasion, according to English reports 6,000 killed and wounded, and 7,000 prisoners. The Anglo-Portuguese army lost, upon the same authority, 5,220.

Every one of these victories was barren of any immediate grand result, unless baffling the designs of the enemy be such.
Even the battle of Salamanca stands in that category, for though Wellington entered Madrid in consequence, he was soon compelled to abandon it and fall back upon Portugal.
The battle of Vittoria was fought when the French were abandoning Spain in consequence of the disasters of the Russian campaign, and the necessity of reinforcing the grand army, then in Germany.
The Allied army (English, Portuguese and Spanish) numbered 80,000 men. They lost 4-750 killed and wounded. The French lost about 6,000.

The battles of Albuera and Barossa were the hardest fought in the Peninsula.
In the first Beresford commanded and in the last Graham.
We may put them against Shiloh and Murfreesboro'.

Such were the battles fought by Wellington in the Peninsula after he took the command for the second time in 1819.
Let any impartial man read the account of them in Napier, Southey, Alison, or any other British historian.
Let him then read even the Yankee accounts of the battles of the last war, and say who did the hardest fighting, and where the greatest slaughter was made.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest cries will be paid.

div3.head: To the Confederate Congress.
div3.p:
Repeal the whole exemption law passed October, 1862; you will thereby add 100,000 more men to the army.
Your provise against extortion is not worth a cent.
Go to our court-houses and churches, see the number of young and likely men staying behind our army privileged by that long exemption act. There is no positive need for one in a hundred of them.
Exempt no man on account of his trade, occupation, or office, either State or Confederate.
If he be so necessary at home, let him hire a substitute.
Equalize the burthen of the war.--Make every person pay one halfe his net gains into the Confederate Treasury made in any manner since April 1st, 1861.
This war has been the lever of manufacturers and speculators to make fortunes out of the misfortunes of their country, while thousands of the best and bravest men we have have freely given up their blood and their lives in their country's defence, many of them leaving poor and helpless wives and orphan children behind them.
Shall those who staid behind, protected in making fortunes, refuse to give one-half their profits to their country made during this want Pay the President and every dollars per month and soldier's rations, and recommend the several States to pay, from Governors down, the same.
This will reduce our expenses many millions per annum — Every man, after paying his debts, shall invest one-half his money in Confederate bonds, bearing 5 per cent. interest.
Pass and execute these laws, and in six months we will have our fifteen Southern States and as many Northwestern and Middle ones as we will let in, and an honorable peace.

At A Meeting held in camp by Captain Wm. J. Dabney's company of Heavy Field Artillery, an unanimous vote of thanks was tendered to Mr. John Purcell, of Richmond, and the committee with whom be was connected, for the many favors of which the said company have been the recipients at their hands.
Weldon, N.C., Feb. 2, 1863

div4.p: On the 4th instant, at a quarter to 9 o'clock A. M. of consumption, Miss Catharine Schleicher, in the 26th year of her age.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at 3 o'clk P. M. to-day from the residence of her brother, George Schleicher, on Union Hill.
On Tuesday, the 3d instant, in Petersburg, from the effects of an accident on the railroad at that point, Geo M. Jones, aged 39 years.
His funeral will take place from the First Presbyterian Church this evening at 3 o'clock. The friends of his family, and of his father-in-law, Mr. Robert Balus, are invited to attend.

on the 3d instant, at the residence of his parents, Henry J. Son of Wm.
T and Ella Lithgow, aged 5 months and 3 days.

lg.l: As the sweet flower that scents the morn,
But withers in the rising day--
Thus lovely seemed the infant a dawn,
Thus swiftly fled his life away.

div4.p:
The funeral will take place at 12 o'clock to-day.
The friends of the family are invited to attend *
in Spotsylvania county, on Sunday, February 1st, Robert Lee, infant son of Absalom P. And Almedia F. Rows, aged 21 months.

lg.l: Though our tears flow fast and faster,
Yet we would not call him back--
We are glad his feet no longer
Tread life's rough and thoray track.
We are glad our heavenly Father
Took him while his heart was pure;
We are glad he did not leave him
We are glad, and yet the tear-drop
That our fireside will be lonely--
We shall miss our darling so.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p:
Died in Richmond, on the 3d instant, after a painful illness of eleven days, Anthony Brown, of Fredericksburg.
Va, aged 17 years 8 months and 3 days.

Farewell, beloved Yoney! Twelve days ago he was in the full vigor of youth, with every prospect of long life; but to-day he is in the cold embrace of death.
That dreadful disease which is now destroying so many of our noblest and best, has deprived his widowed mother of one of the jewels to which her heart-strings clung, with a love that none but a mother can know.
While we deeply mourn this sad bereavement, we bow in humble submission to the will of God, who directeth all things.
We can never meet him on earth, yet we may hope to meet him in Heaven where weeping and sorrow will be no more.
Fredericksburg papers please copy.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A substitute wanted to take the place of a Conscript.
For a good, able bodied man, over 45 years of age, who has received an honorable discharge, a very liberal price will be paid by calling at
63 Main street.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A nice and good Girl, or Woman, accustomed to nursing, and also understands washing and ironing.
She must be willing to go to the country, if desired.
Apply at Mr. S. N. Davis's, corner of 1st and Clay streets.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --at W. R. Polks, No. 75 Main street:
Virginia and Southern Bank Notes,
Virginia Suspended Coupon Bonds,
North Carolina Coupon Bonds,
Missouri Coupon Bonds,
Northern Bank Notes and Exchange,
Yankee Green Backs.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To hire, two good Cooks, to go into the army.
Liberal wages will be paid.
Apply at room No. 39 Arlington House, or the clerk.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Boarders — I will accommodate a few genteel persons with Board, at my house, on 6th st, between Clay and Leigh.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An unfurnished Room, for single gentlemen within ten minutes walk of Richmond Navy Yard.
Address "Box 283," P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--I wish to purchase a good Cook, Washer and Ironer.
For such I will give a good price.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A Military work — Any person having a copy of Polnsett's Cavalry Tactics will obtain for it a liberal price at this office if presented in the next four days.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--an Overseer — I wish to employ a single man. For one that will suit I will hold cut strong inducements.
Apply at the City Water Works.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--$25 reward — Will be paid to any person who will notify the undersigned, through the Dispatch office, of a House which can be rented in a pleasant locality, containing six or eight rooms, furnished or unfurnished, with out houses.
The above reward is based upon immediate possession and terms to suit.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman who has a few hours of the day and night to spare, is desirous of obtaining a situation as Accountant, Copyist, or would keep a set of books, or clerk in any form.
Address "Francis," through Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Lady, thoroughly qualified to teach the higher English branches, Latin, French Music, Drawing, and Oil Paluting on canvas, to instruct one pupil in a private family, near Richmond.
For one who can come well recommended a liberal salary will be given.
Apply to "H., " Box 924; Richmond city Post-Office.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To a reliable man, over 45 years old, not a foreigner, a liberal price will be paid, to go as a Substitute in a company now stationed near the city.
Good references required as to character, &c. Call at the store of

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute over 45 years of age. He will have the privilege of selecting his own service and regiment.
Reference required.
Apply to
div3.closer:
S. H. Owens & Son,
13th st, near Cary. fe 5--3t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --I am willing to pay any reasonable price for a substitute, if immediate application is made at the Cigar Stand at the American Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --For the war; an able bodied man over 45 years of age. Apply at Room No. 23, Linwood House, from 10 to 12 o'clk tomorrow to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For a man over 45, who can come with satisfactory recommendations a liberal price will be paid.
Apply to-day to "B. H," at Messrs J. T. Butler & Co's, between 10 and 12 o'clock A. M.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A good price will be paid.
Apply without delay at room No. 81. Ballard House.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For a man over 45 years of age, and well recommended, a fair price will be paid.
Apply at the store of A Bodeker & Co, No. 10 Main st, between the hours of 9 A. M., and 4 P. M. to-day.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--the Highest price paid for a man over 45 and well recommended.
As he is wanted for a Conscript, he will have the choice of his company.
Call at Room No. 13, Columbian Hotel for three days.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, since July, 1862, a negro man named Willis, belonging jointly to A. R. Miller, dec'd, late of Nottoway county, Va. The said negro is a bright mulatto, about 50 years of age, 5 feet 4 inches high, slightly bald, steps quick, and stoops a little when walking.
He was purchased of Mr. John Pride, of Amelia county, where he has a wife.
He is a good boot and shoemaker, and may be passing as a free man. I will give the above reward if confined in any jail, where we can get him. Address H. T. Millee, or Dr. J. A. Agnew, executors of A. R. Miller's estate, Richmond.

div3.head: Two hundred and fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--For my woman Vina, who escaped from the Bollingbrook Hotel, in Petersburg, the 12th January.
She had on a homespun dress.
She is about 25 years old, dark skin.
She was hired to Mr. John Darmen, in Petersburg, in 1862.
I bought her from Mr. Alpheus A. Kawlett, in Chesterfield.
She may be harbored by some person in or near Petersburg.
If so, I will give fifty dollars in addition to the above reward for their detection.
If caught she may be placed in jail in Petersburg or Richmond.
Address any information concerning her to H. A. Pearce, Richmond, Va., or Mr. Robert F. Jackson, at the office of the South-Side Railroad, Petersburg, Va.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on Monday last, a Negro Woman, named Kitty, aged 40 years. Kitty is black, of medium height, rather stout, has lost a portion of her front teeth, and her eye teeth projects so as to be quite noticeable.
Kitty was originally from the neighborhood of Louisa Court-House, and may be attempting to make her way back.
She took with her several Linsey dresses and other articles of wearing apparel.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and confinement in jail so that I get her again.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my residence on the night of the 25th January, my house boy George.
The said boy is a bright mulatto, 5 feet 8 inches high.
He had on when he left a gray coat, gray pants, shoes that had been smartly worn, and gray cap. He is 22 years old, with fine set of teeth and fall suit of black hair.--He has a little impediment in his speech when spoken to. He may be making his way to our army.
If caught in the county, I will pay $25; if caught out of the county and lodged in jail so that I get him again, I will pay $50.

closer.signed: Verdon P. O., Hanover county, Va.

div3.head: Five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--For William, who left yesterday.
He is about 20 years old, black, has a round face, thick lips, and one of his front teeth out. Had on a military frock coat and cap turned up all around.
He lived the fire part of last year at the Monument Hotel the latter at Mrs. Maynard's.

Eight or the Likely Negroes will be sold to the highest bidder, for cash, at Powhatan Station, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, on Saturday, the 14th of February, 1863.
The sale is for a division under a decree of the County Court of Powhatan in the case of Bass's administrator vs. Forses and others.

div3.head:
Camp battery no. 2, Jan. 31, 1862.
last Chance for Absentees.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General Smith, all members of Capt. T. P. Wilkinson's Company, (C,) 10th Battalion Va. Heavy Artillery, now absent, are notified that they must report to camp by the 10th of February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except the forfeiture of pay" for the time absent.
Should they not report by the time specified they will be considered Deserters, and tried by the new Court Martial now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
John W. Turner.
2d Ld Commanding Co. C,
10th Bat. Va. Heavy Artillery. fe 2--7t*

div3.head:
Camp battery no. 2,
January 31, 1863.
div3.p: last Chance for Absentees.--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General G. W. Smith, all members of Company A. 10th Battalion Virginia Volunteers, Heavy Artillery, now absent, are hereby notified that if they report to camp by the 10th day of February no punishment will be inflicted, except the loss of pay for time absent.--Should they not report by the 10th day of February they will be considered deserters, and tried by the new Military Court now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
